text: I walk around the table and lean down to look at her. She’s resting against the edge, breathing softly—like she’s stolen a fragile moment of peace.
I move the candle aside so the light won’t sting her eyelids. Then I bend carefully, slipping one arm beneath her shoulders. She’s lighter than I expected—light enough to make my chest tighten.
I carry her upstairs. Just as I reach the turn in the stairwell, my foot slips—like I’ve stepped on a trace of spilled oil.
My heart drops. I can’t recover in time. My knee slams into the step and I pitch forward.
I shield her as best I can, but she still jolts in my arms. Her lashes flutter sharply—and then her grey-blue eyes snap open in the dark.
“Sorry! I—I slipped… I was just trying to bring you upstairs.”
She studies me. There’s no anger in her gaze—only the exhaustion of being dragged out of a rare quiet moment. She exhales and steadies herself, slipping from my arms.
She grips the railing. Her steps are slightly unsteady—but stubborn. After two steps, she glances back to make sure I haven’t fallen again.
She opens her door and steps inside. The click of it closing is soft—but it feels like being shut out.
I stand at the top of the stairs, rubbing my aching knee, a quiet sting spreading through my chest.
